title: 105_hr4349
content: The "Long-Term Care Advancement Act of 1998" is the short title of the Act. It includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 2 of the Act provides an exception from penalty tax and exclusion from income for amounts withdrawn from certain retirement plans for qualified long-term care insurance. The "Long-Term Care Advancement Act of 1998" amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide an exception from penalty tax for distributions from retirement plans used for qualified long-term care insurance premiums. The Long-Term Care Advancement Act of 1998 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow deductions for qualified long-term care insurance premiums paid by an individual or their spouse. Premiums are treated as amounts not paid for medical care, and no double benefit is allowed unless the taxpayer elects otherwise. The definition of a qualified long-term care insurance contract is based on section 7702B(b) of the Code. The Long-Term Care Advancement Act of 1998 allows deductions for qualified long-term care insurance premiums paid by an individual or their spouse. Premiums are excluded from gross income if the contracts are licensed for sale in the state where the policy was purchased. Additionally, amounts withdrawn from certain plans to pay long-term care premiums are excluded from income. SEC. 139 allows distributions from individual retirement plans and section 401(k) plans for long-term care insurance. The amount includible in gross income by reason of distributions from individual retirement plans or section 401(k) plans shall be reduced by eligible long-term care premiums paid for qualified long-term care insurance. Special rules apply to section 401(k) plans. The section discusses the rules regarding distributions from individual retirement plans or section 401(k) plans and how eligible long-term care premiums paid for qualified long-term care insurance can reduce the amount includible in gross income. It also mentions that distributions permitted under a plan or arrangement that are excludable from gross income by this section do not cause disqualification. The term 'qualified long-term care insurance contract' is defined in accordance with section 7702B(b). The section discusses distributions permitted from certain plans to pay long-term care premiums, including the definition of a qualified long-term care insurance contract as per section 139(c). Amendments are made to section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) to allow for distributions for long-term care insurance premiums. Amendments are made to allow distributions for long-term care insurance premiums from certain plans, including section 403(b)(11) and section 457(d)(1). Amendments are made to allow distributions for long-term care insurance premiums from certain plans, including section 403(b)(11) and section 457(d)(1). Conforming amendments are also made to sections 72(t)(2)(B) and 401(k). Amendments allow tax-free withdrawals from individual retirement plans for long-term care premiums. Amendments made to allow tax-free withdrawals from individual retirement plans and section 401(k) plans for long-term care insurance. Effective date for these changes is after December 31, 1997. Additionally, a new credit is introduced for taxpayers with certain persons requiring custodial care in their households. The new credit allows individuals with qualified persons in their household to receive a $500 credit per person, which is reduced by $50 for every $1,000 of modified adjusted gross income above a threshold amount. The term "threshold amount" for the new credit is $110,000 for joint returns, $75,000 for unmarried individuals, and $55,000 for married individuals filing separately. A "qualified person" includes parents, ancestors, chronically ill individuals, and those who live with the taxpayer for more than half the year. The tax credit applies to qualified persons living with the taxpayer for more than half the year, including parents, ancestors, and chronically ill individuals. Special rules apply for stepfathers or stepmothers. Phase-in rules apply for taxable years before 2002. The tax credit amount varies based on the calendar year, with adjustments for inflation starting from 2002. The tax credit amount is adjusted for inflation annually, rounding to the nearest multiple of $50. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997.
